titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Lillian E. Travis Papers relating to William Glackens and Charles Prendergast, 1917-1984, bulk 1930-1984, in the Archives of American Art AAA.travlill
Travis (Lillian E.) papers relating to William Glackens and Charles Prendergast
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Joy Goodwin

note.p: This finding aid was created from a MARC collection-level record. 306783

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-07-06T12:51-0400

did.unittitle: Lillian E. Travis papers relating to William Glackens and Charles Prendergast
did.abstract: The Lillian E. Travis papers relating to William Glackens and Charles Prendergast measure 0.2 linear feet and date from 1917-1984. The majority of the collection consists of photographs of William Glackens, his family, and friends, Charles and Maurice Prendergast. The papers also include Ira Glackens's letters to Marion Travis and printed material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Lillian E. Travis papers relating to William Glackens and Charles Prendergast measure 0.2 linear feet and date from 1917-1984. The majority of the collection consists of photographs of William Glackens, his family, and friends, Charles and Maurice Prendergast. The papers also include Ira Glackens's letters to Marion Travis and printed material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 3 series.

list.item: Series 1: Ira Glackens Letters to Marion Travis, 1961-1984 (Box 1; 2 folders)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Lillian E. Travis (1886-1961) lived in New York. Prior to 1900, she married John C. Travis and had two daughters, Marion (1900-1985) and Viola (1905-1982). She divorced in 1907 and moved to New York. Travis enrolled at the Art Students League, where she became acquainted with Edith Dimock Glackens. Lillian and her daughters formed close ties to the Glackens family and their circle of friends, which included Maurice Prendergast, Charles Prendergast and his wife, Eugenie. Struck by Lillian's rich golden hair, William Glackens had her serve as his model for his painting, The Shoppers. Marion Travis and Viola Travis Crawford were also close friends of William Glackens's son, Ira and his wife, Nancy. Lillian E. Travis died in New York in 1961.

American realist painter, William Glackens (1870-1938) lived and worked in New York City and Westport, Connecticut. He studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts under Robert Henri. Glackens began his career as a commercial illustrator for newspapers and periodicals. He later turned to painting and was part of "The Eight," a group of artists dedicated to portraying realistic scenes of daily urban life.

Painter, sculptor, and artisan frame-maker, Charles Prendergast (1863-1948) lived and worked with his brother, Maurice (1858-1924) in Boston, Massachusetts before moving to New York City in 1914. Charles achieved prominence as a craftsman and framemaker, and later specialized in painted, gilded, and incised panels of exotic and folk subjects.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Lillian E. Travis papers relating to William Glackens and Charles Prendergast are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed to a minimal level and a finding aid prepared in 2013 by Joy Goodwin. The Archives of American Art has implemented minimal processing tactics when possible in order to increase information about and access to more of our collections. Minimal processing included arrangement to the series and folder levels. Generally, items within folders were simply verified with folder titles, but not arranged further. Folders within boxes were not numbered. The collection was rehoused in archival containers and folders, but not all staples and clips were removed.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated to the Archives of American Art by Lillian E. Travis's granddaughter, Sarah Crawford Fox, in 2012.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Lillian E. Travis papers relating to William Glackens and Charles Prendergast, 1917-1984. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

did.unittitle: Ira Glackens Letters to Marion Travis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of seven handwritten letters from Ira Glackens to Marion Travis. The letters mainly refer to Ira's daily activities and book projects. There are some references to their mutual acquaintances. Also found are holiday cards from Ira and Nancy Glackens to Marion Travis.

did.unittitle: Ira Glackens Letters to Marion Travis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed material includes scattered exhibition brochures and catalogs, newpaper and magazine clippings. Catalogs document William Glackens's solo and group exhibitions at Kraushaar Art Galleries and the Whitney Studio Galleries. Two issues of the American Federation of Art's Magazine of Art feature essay-length reviews on the work of William Glackens and Maurice Prendergast. Some of the printed material is rare.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains mostly black and white snapshots of William Glackens, his wife, Edith Dimock Glackens, family and friends at their home in Westport, Connecticut. There are a few snapshots of the Glackens family on their travels. Also found are images of Charles and Eugene Prendergast, presumably at the Glackens home. Some of the individuals and venues are not identified.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Photographs are arranged in rough chronological order.

did.unittitle: Photographs of William Glackens and Family, Maurice Prendergast, and Charles and Eugenie Prendergast
